The 'work_mem' setting in PostgreSQL specifies the amount of memory to be used by internal sort operations and hash tables before writing to temporary disk files. It is expressed in kilobytes and can be set to a positive integer value. Next, we need to check if there are any special values within this range that alter its regular behavior significantly, such as disabling a feature or drastically changing how the system operates. After reviewing the PostgreSQL documentation and other resources, it is found that 'work_mem' does not have any special values such as -1 or 0 that change its behavior in a non-linear or non-standard way. All positive integer values scale the memory usage linearly, and there are no indications of special values that break this natural order.
